review_title: NPs are just low paid, abused, workhorse RNs
pros: Friendly unit staff & NP colleagues are great to work with
cons: The overall culture of Caromont, it seems, is to treat PMHNPs as nothing but workhorse RNs. PMHNPs Do not function in the capacity of the nurse practitioners that they are trained and licensed as. They are not permitted to make diagnostic/ treatment decisions on their own. Every decision must be reviewed ad nauseam and decided upon  by the physician. Additionally, the physicians dump all the work on the NPs- SO, the NP makes no decisions and Carries out all the work while the physicians sit around and play/talk on their cell phones and take care of personal business. Take note, this  will absolutely be your day on the psychiatry unit if you choose to work here. You will be told that the unit is like “family,” “we all support each other,” “we celebrate each others birthdays,” etc, etc. They will paint a beautiful picture & tell you anything-  but take heart, nothing could be further from the truth. NPs are subjected to  abusive treatment that is condescending, controlling, belittling, & passive aggressive, & you will be deceived. Multiple NPs have been subjected to routine gaslighting. This treatment has left them feeling beat down & fearful. They cannot keep any NPs in the psychiatry dept for more than a few months due to the treatment. What matters here is the “hierarchy.” The patients do NOT come first, the physicians egos do. In addition to all this, NPs  have to take a salary cut in order to come work here ( & NPs are willing to do so with the glossy picture they paint).  It doesn’t matter if you’re a new grad, or have years of experience, they don’t care, everyone gets the same pay. Why would anyone want to work for less money, in an abusive environment, where the work is not allocated fairly, your experience counts for nothing, and you cannot even function as what you are trained and licensed as? I do not recommend working here and would urge you to run far away from this backward place.

pros: Friendly Staff for the most part. There are staff members who are fighting a new system that is going to effect the production of offices and many errors will be made. They need to run reports for errors, and pay attention to the workques.
cons: Pay is not comparable to other facilities in the surrounding area. You loose good Certified people and Staff to other hospitals that pay better and treat their staff with more regard.

It makes it hard for someone who just wants to work hard and not go to work to make friends.

review_title: Instability at its finest and Management at its worst!
pros:
Coworkers who work on the same level
Pay is comparable to other hospitals
cons:
Management in ALL Levels.   I have worked at Gaston Memorial Hospital/Caromont for many years. In the past few years I have seen so many people suddenly disappear from the company.  There is no value of years of loyal and hard work.  Look at management and you will find inept people overseeing those even more experienced and qualified.  It's a great mix for corruption and disaster.   Check out the turnover rates in many of the departments...  that should tell you what you need to know!  
If you want to advance...  it's who you know, not what you know.

pros: On site cafeteria (with crappy overpriced food, but at least it's convenient)
cons: Pay for most positions is not typically competitive with for-profit competitors. Vast majority of employees are long-time local - meaning management mistreats and  runs over their workers with little regard, on the assumption they aren't going anywhere. Corporate politics influence everything (think "House of Cards" in a healthcare setting), so managers and director level personnel must tread carefully. Even if you play the politics right but are high performance, someone will see you as a threat and as competition and try to neutralize you - so aim for mediocrity if you work here.

pros: Excellent people to work for and with. Within the telecommunications group there's a strong team oriented atmosphere. The vacation flexibility is excellent. Our ability to work together as a team is excellent.
cons: Pay is not up to industry standard. There is absolutely no training. The raises are not up to nation wide standards. Leadership is disconnected preferring to spend all their time in meetings.

pros: Benefits through the hospital, Most of staff truly cares about the patients
cons:
Lack of staff to provide quality care required, Unorganized and no quick access to supplies when quickly needed. Some nights no CNA after 7pm on assisted living,
Very little to no support from upper management.

pros: The orientation process for new employees is the best I have seen throughout my experience working in healthcare. Also, they really want to help new graduate nurse interns succeed. Everything has been organized and put into place for a new employee to come in and feel like family, not a number. The pay rates are the best in the area and even with gas prices being so high, it is still worth the commute to work at Gaston.
cons: Distance to travel if you are not from that area.

review_title: Great pay and good work environment.
pros: Great pay and flexible hours. Supportive of continuing education and certification encouragement. Excellent surgical services, critical care services, anesthesia services.
cons: Being on call frequently is frustrating on occasion, but comes with the territory and night shift staff cuts down on time being called as frequently. Management is improving. Would like to see more enforcement of policies against rule offenders.

cons: The amount of disrespect that is allowed to go on is crazy. I have never worked anywhere in my life that allowed anyone to act the way the majority of the nurses and doctors are allowed to. I left due to the lack of respect

cons: Not many cons. For work that is done the pay should be increased. Sometimes upper management is not in tune with the work force.

job_title: Critical Care Nurse in Durham, NC
pros: I kept people alive at least
cons:
There are so many. Where to start? Management is the obvious place. The blind lead the blind. If you arent in the "club", guess what, there is no room for advancement. The clinical ladder is merely a way for the clinicians to get their grunt work done and the "raises" are a joke. 

Drug diversion was rampant, but instead of addressing it, it was easier to pick on the nurses who stood against management. I watched shift managers double dose patients to keep them docile so they could surf the net, when I brought it to upper managements attention, the witch hunt started. I personally know of five nurses who diverted in the units, one turned herself in, two were caught, one quit and one died. Yeah, thats right, instead of stepping in, management allowed her to divert until she OD'd. Again, all this from myself and 9 other nurses fell on deaf ears. Interesting how none of that nine is still there.

Nurses were sleeping with doctors in the break rooms, nurses were writing their won narcotics orders and shift management was taking assignments so their pets could go get their hair done. Now, this happens every where, dont be no naive, you say. No, it doesnt. I am a 20+ year critical care veteran and having worked at Duke, ECU, CMC, Presby, MD Anderson and some of the nations better facilities, I can honestly tell you, it does not. I stayed in bedside nursing as a travel nurse for another four years after leaving this place. But no assignment, not even Hawaii, could get the bad taste out of my mouth. I left the bed side and have never looked back. Public, beware. This facility is staffed with nurses that try hard, but if they arent in managements back pocket, it wont matter at the end of the day.

pros: There are some very godly people who work here. They are a pleasure to be around.
cons: Toxic work environment where you are always one step away from getting fired. Leadership will bully you and then scare you by threatening to not renew your contract. You either kiss the ground they walk on or you are without a job. So many people hate this place because of some in leadership.
